msDesc.head: Single-text codex of The Prick of Conscience with expansions; xiv end.

msItem.title: The Prick of Conscience
msItem.rubric: Incipit stimulus consciencie a Ricardo heremite de hampole compositus gracie dei subdito terminatur (fol. 8r)
msItem.incipit:
T he myȝt of þe fadir almyȝtty
The wisdom of þe sone al wytty
msItem.explicit:
ȝif he hope þat god is almyȝtty
And he þat shal it here oþer see
msItem.note:
Imperfect, lacking leaves in the first quire, one leaf (between folios 23 and 24) and a final leaf (after folio 138) containing the last twenty one lines. Text expanded: 11,020/9,526 lines. Belongs to the Main Version of The Prick of Conscience, Group II. A member of the so-called Lollard subgroup, which contains two interpolations and one rearrangement with an attack on the clergy, Latin prose also incorporating anti-clerical sentiment, and the transferal of some text from Book V (6346-409) to the end of Book VII (between lines 9474 and 9475) - on this group see Allen, 1927, pp. 387-94.
Recorded as MV 61 in Lewis and McIntosh (1982), who also note that this manuscript is related to London, Society of Antiquaries, MS 687; Manchester, John Rylands University Library, MS English 90; and Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS e. Musaeo 76 (the other surviving Lollard subgroup texts). See Killian (2017).
Ashmole 60 is one of five manuscripts that attributes the poem to Richard Rolle of Hampole.
e-LALME and Lewis and McIntosh note the dialect of the scribe is located to the Isle of Ely.
Edited in Richard Morris's Prick of Conscience: A Corrected and Amplified Reading Text, Early English Text Society Original Series 342, eds Ralph Hanna and Sarah Wood (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013).
DIMEV 5398

msItem.title: Treatise in reproof of worldiness in the clergy
msItem.incipit: non desit nelus boni nec sciencia
msItem.explicit:
For þanne shal no mede wiþ outen merre
Be mettid for deeþ bon bettre or werre
msItem.note:
Imperfect, lacking material at the beginning and after folio 3. Middle English rhyming couplets intermixed with Latin prose. In this copy, inserted before the beginning of the poem, line 1.
One other witness of this extract is preserved in BodL, MS e Musaeo 198.
Edited in Frederick J. Furnivall, Ballads from Manuscripts (London: Ballad Society, 1863; repr. New York: AMS, 1968), 1.63; and extracts in Hope Emily Allen, Writings Attributed to Richard Rolle (New York: Modern Language Association of America, 1927), 391-2.

msItem.title: The pains of hell
msItem.incipit: Nunc sequitur de pena que est mutua visio dampnatorum
msItem.explicit: vobis tribuat et veram penetenciam antequam vos de hoc seculo tollat . Amen .
msItem.note: The largest addition, of 33 1/2 folios, in the middle of the discussion of the seventh and eighth pains of hell in Book VI (between lines 6894 and 6895). Primarily sermonizing Latin prose with quotations from the scriptures and the fathers, interspersed with short extracts of Middle English rhyming couplets.

This copy also contains a Book VIII, which is made of material normally in Book V (lines 6346-409) which has been transposed to the end of Book VII (after line 9475) to form a new Book (on fols. 136r-137v).

handDesc.handNote: One hand throughout, in a neat anglicana formata.

decoDesc.decoNote: The first letter of every line of Middle English verse is highlighted with a subtle yellow colour wash.

The beginning of each Book is marked with a four to six-line decorated blue initial with elaborate red flourishes, extending into a three-sided red and blue bar border with red flourishes. The only exception of Book VI (fol. 82v), which opens with a less ornate three-line initial in the same style. All initials are accompanied by a rubricated Incipit.
Rubricated rhyming braces on Middle English couplets throughout.
Rubricated Book numbers given in the upper left margin of every leaf.

As is typical in the corpus, the section on the fifteen days before Christ's coming (Book V ll.4758-4817) is annotated with rubricated roman numerals 1-15 in the margin of fols. 63v-64r. Similar numerals are given for the ten things men may see at the day of dread (Book V ll.3966-3990, fols. 54v-55r), and the fourteen pains (Book VI ll.6547-6578).

The first three glosses are given in the margin and rubricated. Thereafter glosses are given in-line with Middle English verse and rubricated, with the exception of the second interpolation (fols. 88r-104r), in which some of the glosses are marginal.
Blue paraphs mark the start of Latin prose extracts, and alternating red and blue paraphs mark moments of textual division within Middle English verse extracts.
One decorated initial mid-Book, a six-line blue lombardic capitol with red flourishes, on fol. 100v.
Some passages of Latin prose underlined in red.
Decorative rubricated line fillers in Latin prose.

physDesc.additions:
Bookmark or cut-and-fold-tab (following Sawyer, 2016) on fol. 77 in which a strip of parchment has been cut from the page, folded, and fed through a slit.
A sixteenth-century hand annotates four lines of verse at the foot of fol. 1r: While I am poore, to riche men will not give .
Lest iustly fole, men terme me whilst I live .
Or yt the worlde suspitious will say .
The poore man beges, when he dothe give away .. It is signed below W.A..
A note recording Rolle's death appears in the upper margin of fol. 1r, in a sixteenth century hand(?). A different hand of a similar period annotates Ricardus Rolle Eremita de Hampoll on the final folio.
Pen trials on fol. 38v.
Medieval nota bene marks, possibly by the scribe, at fols. 47v (3398), 48r (3446), and throughout the second interpolation (fols. 88r-104r).

binding.p: Late seventeenth-century calf binding over pasteboards, typical of Elias Ashmole's style, rebacked. The edges of both boards are decorated with concentric tool framing, with triple tooling on the margin closest to the spine on both boards. The board edges are tooled with a repeating semi-circle pattern, also typical of Ashmole's bindings.

The spine has been rebacked, and shows five raised sewing supports covering thick cords which support both composite parts. The shelf mark ASH. 60 is embossed on the central spine panel. The typeset of the shelf mark is similar, but not identical, to Ashmole's typeset (varying in the height of letters and thickness of vertical strokes in characters A and H), and Ashmole's embossed crest is missing from the second panel (see e.g. MS Ashmole 44). The board-covers also show evidence of having been lifted up at the spine-edge to allow for the spine-cover to be adhered beneath them.
The sewing stations of Ashmole's binding do not follow the original sewing stations. There is evidence of a prior binding that included at least seven sewing stations.

There are no end bands. The sewing supports are laced into the boards using shortened single-hole lacing without channels. The board edges are tooled with a repeating zig-zag pattern typical of Ashmole's bindings. The inner rear board bears an inscription typical of the Bodleian's in-house bindery, with the initial H and the date, partially obscured, 3 - 12 - 00

history.provenance: The name Wyllyam Harrys is recorded twice on folio 30r in a sixteenth century hand. Harrys also leaves an erased note in the margin of folio 28v, illegible under UV.

The manuscript was owned by Elias Ashmole (1617–1692) in the seventeenth century. It is uncertain when Ashmole acquired the manuscript, but he is responsible for its current binding. Ashmole also purchased another copy of The Prick of Conscience, MS Ashmole 52. He does not mention acquiring either manuscript in his diary or correspondence.
Bequeathed to the Ashmolean Museum by Elias Ashmole in 1692 as part of his donation of 1,100 printed books and 600 manuscripts.
history.acquisition: The manuscript was kept in the Ashmolean until 1860, when the collection was transferred to the Bodleian Library .
